content.description:
Numquam sum magis de occupationibusoccupatio, -onis, f. = negotium, -i meis questusqueror, -i, questus sum: to complain,1 
quae me non sunt passae aut proficiscentem te valetudinisvaletudo, -inis, f.: health 
causa in CampaniamCampania, -ae, f.: Campania (an area of central Italy) prosequiprosequor, -i = sequor, -i aut profectam e vestigio 
subsequisubsequor, -i = sequor, -i.
 1:The subject of questus sum is Pliny the Younger.↩
content.question: In line 2, what does sunt passae mean?

unit.text: 3: Pliny's Letters: Ghosts and Apparitions, Letters to Trajan and Calpurnia, and Teacher's Choice - Latin Prose

skill.text: 1.A: Identify the meaning of Latin words and phrases.
